bestBHT.bht: The insults and mockery imply the contempt of the people towards Jesus, as the dazed multitude and the rulers join in on the mocking. Challenging Jesus to save himself if he is truly the Messiah and the chosen King, the crowd's derisive tone contrasts with his claim to be the Savior of others. Regardless of any discrepancies, it is clear that the Christ of God must be taken together.

Henry Alford: The insults of the people are by no means excluded, even if the words with them be omitted: nay they are implied..."
To find a discrepancy with Matthew and Mark here, is surely unfair:—the people’s standing looking on, does not describe their mind towards Jesus: St. Luke reports no more than he had before him...
I prefer the former: but either way, the Christ of God must be taken together.
Marvin Vincent: If he. The A. V. does not give the contemptuous emphasis on ou=tov, this fellow.
Philip Schaff: A crowd would not, however, remain still long on such an occasion, and others would be coming from the city.
As if in contrast with the people, but the latter joined in the mockery.
The tone is that of contempt.
Archibald T. Robertson: A graphic picture of the dazed multitude.
He had claimed to be just this.
These rulers were having their day at last.
John Gill: He saved others; let him save himself."
If he be Christ, the Messiah, he and his followers give out he is."
Christ was not chosen to be the Son of God; he was so by nature; but he was chosen to be a servant, as the text cited shows, to be a Mediator between God and man, and the Saviour of his people.
John Wesley: If thou be the Christ; Luke 23:37.
If thou be the king — The priests deride the name of Messiah: the soldiers the name of king.

bhtAttempts.bht: The insults and mockery directed towards Jesus by the people are implied in this verse, highlighting the dazed and contemptuous attitude of the multitude. Regardless of the discrepancy between Matthew, Mark, and Luke, it is clear that the Christ of God must be taken together. The rulers, who had long awaited their moment, joined in the mockery. The crowd's contemptuous tone is emphasized, while some individuals challenge Jesus to save himself if he truly is the Messiah and the chosen King.

The insults and mockery from the people imply their contempt towards Jesus. The dazed multitude, along with the rulers, join in on the mockery, challenging Jesus to save himself if he is truly the Messiah and the chosen King. This verse emphasizes the derisive tone of the crowd, contrasting their attitude with Jesus, who claimed to be the Savior of others. Regardless of any discrepancies, it is clear that the Christ of God must be taken together.

The insults and mockery imply the contempt of the people towards Jesus, as the dazed multitude and the rulers join in on the mocking. Challenging Jesus to save himself if he is truly the Messiah and the chosen King, the crowd's derisive tone contrasts with his claim to be the Savior of others. Regardless of any discrepancies, it is clear that the Christ of God must be taken together.

The insults and mockery displayed the contempt of the people towards Jesus. The dazed multitude, along with the rulers, joined in on the mocking. Challenging Jesus to save himself if he is truly the Messiah and the chosen King, the crowd's derisive tone was evident. Regardless of any discrepancies, it is clear that the Christ of God must be taken together. The verse emphasizes the contrast between the people's attitude and Jesus' claim to be the Savior of others.

The insults and mockery revealed the people's contempt towards Jesus, as the dazed multitude and rulers joined in. The crowd challenged Jesus, demanding him to save himself if he truly was the Messiah and chosen King. Despite any discrepancies, it is evident that the Christ of God must be considered as a whole. The contrasting tones of the crowd and Jesus are clear, with Jesus claiming to be the Savior of others while the people mock him.
